Sx4.T1.caption: Table 1: Statistics of datasets.
Sx4.T1.table:
Dataset User # Item # Interaction #
Movielens-10M 37,962 4,819 1,371,473
Douban-Movie 6,809 1,5012 173,766
references: We follow the preprocessing steps used in DICE (Zheng et al. 2021) for the dataset. First, we randomly select 40% of the movie review data with the same probability (these data can be considered as (Zheng et al. 2021) for the dataset. First, we randomly select 40% of the movie review data with the same probability (these data can be considered as unbiased and represent recommendation results under a completely random strategy). Then, we use 10% and 20% of the random data as the validation set and test set, respectively, to evaluate the model’s debiasing performance on unbiased data. Finally, the remaining 10% of the random data and the other 60% of unselected samples form the training set. In other words, the training, validation, and test data are split in a 70 : 10 : 20 : 70 10 : 20 70:10:20 70 : 10 : 20 ratio. We include 10% unbiased data in the training set due to the requirements of CausE  70 : 10 : 20 : 70 10 : 20 70:10:20 70 : 10 : 20 70 : 10 : 20 70 70: :10 10: :20 20 : 70 10 : 20 : 70 10 : 20 : 70 10 : :70 7010 10 : 20 : : 20 2070:10:20 70:10:2070 : 10 : 20 70 : 10 : 20 ratio. We include 10% unbiased data in the training set due to the requirements of CausE (Bonner and Vasile 2018). Table  (Bonner and Vasile 2018). Table 1 shows the statistics of the processed datasets.

Sx4.T2.caption: Table 2: The performance of all methods on Movielens-10M. The “original” indicates that only the backbone is used, with no additional causal debiasing methods. The best results are highlighted in bold, and the second-best results are underlined.

\widehat{W}_{u,i}<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="Sx4.SSx2.p1.1.m1.2d">over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT</annotation>
over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which capture the causal relationship. “Imp.” represents the percentage improvement in Recall for each method compared to the original model. The best results are highlighted in bold, and the second-best results are underlined.

The analysis of Tables 2 and 3 shows that CIV4Rec and CIV4Rec-Causal significantly improve performance metrics compared to the original backbone, with the highest improvement reaching 39.71%, demonstrating statistical significance and the superiority of our approach. Notably, CIV4Rec consistently outperforms CIV4Rec-Causal, aligning with the understanding that incorporating appropriate confounders enhances recommendation performance. This confirms that <math alttext="Z_{c}" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1a">
    <msub id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">
      <mi id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.2" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.2.cmml">Z</mi>
      <mi id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.3" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.3.cmml">c</mi>
    </msub>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1b">
      <apply id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1">
        <csymbol cd="ambiguous" id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.1.cmml" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1">subscript</csymbol>
        <ci id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.2.cmml" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.2">𝑍</ci>
        <ci id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.3.cmml" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.3">𝑐</ci>
      </apply>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1c">Z_{c}</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math> in CIV4Rec effectively captures relevant confounders in user interaction data.

𝑍<ci id="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.3.cmml" xref="Sx4.SSx2.p2.1.m1.1.1.3">𝑐</ci>

italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in CIV4Rec effectively captures relevant confounders in user interaction data.

Tables 2 and 3 reveal several key insights: (1) IPS-based debiasing methods perform poorly because they rely heavily on the inverse propensity score, which is closely tied to the data distribution. In our experiments, training was conducted on a biased dataset, while testing was performed on an unbiased dataset, leading to inconsistent data distributions between the training and validation sets. (2) Similarly, CausE showed suboptimal performance because it requires an unbiased dataset during training to align the user-item embedding representations. (3) Although DICE and DCCL, two debiasing methods based on causal graph assumptions, improve recommendation performance, they do not achieve optimal results. This is because these methods target specific biases based on assumed causal graphs, while real-world datasets often contain diverse biases due to latent confounding factors, limiting their effectiveness.

over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which capture the causal relationship. “Imp.” represents the percentage improvement in Recall for each method compared to the original model. The best results are highlighted in bold, and the second-best results are underlined.

The analysis of Tables 2 and 3 shows that CIV4Rec and CIV4Rec-Causal significantly improve performance metrics compared to the original backbone, with the highest improvement reaching 39.71%, demonstrating statistical significance and the superiority of our approach. Notably, CIV4Rec consistently outperforms CIV4Rec-Causal, aligning with the understanding that incorporating appropriate confounders enhances recommendation performance. italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in CIV4Rec effectively captures relevant confounders in user interaction data.

Tables 2 and 3 reveal several key insights: (1) IPS-based debiasing methods perform poorly because they rely heavily on the inverse propensity score, which is closely tied to the data distribution. In our experiments, training was conducted on a biased dataset, while testing was performed on an unbiased dataset, leading to inconsistent data distributions between the training and validation sets. (2) Similarly, CausE showed suboptimal performance because it requires an unbiased dataset during training to align the user-item embedding representations. (3) Although DICE and DCCL, two debiasing methods based on causal graph assumptions, improve recommendation performance, they do not achieve optimal results. This is because these methods target specific biases based on assumed causal graphs, while real-world datasets often contain diverse biases due to latent confounding factors, limiting their effectiveness.
